newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia warned to beware of Asia on superhighway.
newsitem.headline: Australia warned to beware of Asia on superhighway.

text.p: Australia has been warned it risks being overtaken by its Asian rivals on the information superhighway unless it shifts into gear urgently.
A report released by a coalition of top Australian chief executives has found Singapore and Malaysia is leaping ahead in the "on-line revolution" in Asia, catching Australia napping.
"It's a slumbering issue and it can't be allowed to stay asleep," said bank chief executive Don Mercer, president of the Australian Coalition of Service Industries.
The coalition commissioned the study out of fears Australia could fall behind in the emerging area of on-line commerce and trade, which is turning the Internet into a global marketplace.

The report notes Australia's relatively high cost of tapping into the Internet, a world-wide computer network with tens of millions of users. Its author also says "ancient" cables linking Australia to the rest of the world are clogged with traffic.
"Our competitors in the global economy are already taking significant steps to embrace the on-line economy and, as first movers, may capture an important advantage," the report said.
"Nations failing to embrace the on-line economy are likely to see tradeable services supplied by offshore companies, high unemployment and lower economic growth," it added.

Australia is seen as quick to adopt new technology with ambitions to become a regional business hub in Asia. Its two telecommunications carriers are spending a total of A$6.5 billion on rolling out broad-band cable across the country.

But cables linking Australia to the rest of the world are groaning, with Internet traffic out of Australia swelling 15 percent a month and local complaints that capacity on these cables is already scarce and too expensive, the report said.
"If Australia does need more capacity, as seems likely, it will need to talk action urgently, as Asian competitors appear well positioned for a pre-emptive strike," it added.

The report's author, information technology expert Clem Doharty, said fibre-optic cables linking Australia and North America were "ancient" and thin compared with the thicker cables Asian nations were using to hook up with the West.
"There are major cables linking Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Thailand to Europe and to North America," Doharty said.
No reliable figures are kept in Australia on the small but growing balance of trade on the Internet, where firms ranging from banks to book-sellers have already set up shop world-wide.
But the coalition's Mercer, who is chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, said Australia was widely believed to be trading in the red on the Internet.
